// using the "Delay" option. setTimeout() does not work in collection runs.
console.log(`‚è≥ Polling attempt ${pollAttempt}/${maxPollAttempts} - configure delay in Collection Runner settings`);
pm.test("Session not found - OAuth flow needs to be initiated", function () {
console.log("‚ö†Ô∏è Session not found. Please create a session first using the 'Create session' request.");
console.log("The OAuth flow needs to be initiated before fetching session information.");
// Stop the collection run since we can't proceed without a valid session
// Check if the session has a token
console.log("‚úì Authorization completed after", pollAttempt, "polling attempts");
// Token not yet available - check if we should continue polling
console.log(`üîÑ Polling attempt ${newPollAttempt}/${maxPollAttempts}: Token not yet available`);
console.log(`   Waiting for user to complete OAuth authorization...`);
// Loop back to this same request to poll again
console.log("‚ùå Maximum polling attempts reached (", maxPollAttempts, "attempts)");
console.log("‚ö†Ô∏è  OAuth authorization was not completed within the timeout period");
pm.test("OAuth flow timeout - authorization not completed", function () {
pm.expect.fail("OAuth authorization was not completed within the timeout period. Please authorize manually and re-run the collection.");

request.description:
Once the user returns back to the CLI we grab the session data with the token id that will allow us to do our Git calls

---

The id in the path param denotes the session id received in the create session call. This endpoint is used to fetch the session information (and token) from the server. The response varies based on the tokenType that we sent in the previous call

If **token_type = bulk_import** -> the response contains the actual access token

If **token_type = api_repository** -> the response contains the id of the token stored in the OAuth token table, which can be used later in API Git flows.

request.description:
We are using this to create the new SDK to Gitghub integration. The `Variables` field can be used to store any data we might need for our service. If you look at the `Body` in this request it will show you some of the stuff we should store including:

- `repository`: the repo the SDKs will be placed in
    
- `branch`: the branch the SDKs will be pushed to
    
- `owner`: the owner of this integration who will be credited with the creation of this branch
    
- `path`: the path to the directory that will hold the SDKs
    

**Request Body**

| Field | Description |
| --- | --- |
| name | Name of the integration. |
| rule | Type of integration. Eg: monitor_run_slack |
| entity | Type of Postman entity. Eg: collection, jobTemplate |
| executor | ID of the Postman entity that the integration is to be configured on. |
| variables | List of variables required for integration. The structure of this field is dependent on the type of integration. |

response.name: 403 - Insufficient permissions on the entity
404 - Entity not found
400 - Required parameter missing
400 - Missing mandatory variables
403 - Incorrect/Expired Token
200 - Create Success

query.description: Can be set to 0 or 1; toggles returning status in the API.

request.description:
Get details of a given integration.

The `populateStatus` parameter is used if we want the `status` field in the response to be populated. If it is `false`, then `status` is set to `null`.

> **Note**: If the user has permission to view sensitive variables, they are added in this API's response as well. Learn more about the permissions [here](https://postmanlabs.atlassian.net/l/cp/TjMntbrn).

response.name: 400 - Token is invalid and user_id missing[Consider removing user_id altogether as endpoint is functional without it]
404 - Attempt to fetch an integration that does not exist
403 - Request to fetch an integration not owned by you
403 - Incorrect/Expired Token
200 - Success without status
200 - Success with status populated
200 - Success with sensitive information (Shown to creator of integration)
